   613â†’### `/flow start [max-iterations]`
   614â†’
   615â†’Starts autonomous flow execution.
   616â†’
   617â†’```bash

   621â†’```

   623â†’**What happens:**
   624â†’1. Validates prerequisites (docs/, PRD files, incomplete stories)
   625â†’2. Scans for all PRD files in `docs/`
   626â†’3. Identifies incomplete stories (`passes: false`)
   627â†’4. For each story:
   628â†’   - **MEMORY LOADING PHASE**: Loads related PRD memories + previous story memories
   629â†’   - **IMPLEMENTATION PHASE**: Spawns specialist agents for each mavenStep
   630â†’   - **QUALITY CHECKS**: Runs typecheck and lint
   631â†’   - **MEMORY CREATION PHASE**: Creates story memory file
   632â†’   - Commits changes with standardized format
   633â†’   - Marks story as complete in PRD
   634â†’5. Continues until max iterations or all PRDs complete

   998â†’## Feature-Based Architecture
   999â†’
  1000â†’Maven Flow enforces a strict feature-based structure for all new code:
  1001â†’
  1002â†’```
  1003â†’src/
  1004â†’â”œâ”€â”€ app/                    # Entry points, routing
  1005â†’â”œâ”€â”€ features/               # Isolated feature modules
  1006â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ auth/              # Cannot import from other features
  1007â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ api/           # API calls
  1008â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ components/    # Feature components
  1009â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ hooks/         # Custom hooks
  1010â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ types/         # TypeScript types
  1011â†’â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ index.ts       # Public exports
  1012â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ dashboard/
  1013â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [feature-name]/
  1014â†’â”œâ”€â”€ shared/                # Shared code (no feature imports)
  1015â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ui/                # Reusable components
  1016â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ api/               # Backend clients (Firebase, Supabase)
  1017â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ utils/             # Utilities
  1018â†’â””â”€â”€ [type: "app"]
  1019â†’```
  1020â†’
  1021â†’### Architecture Rules
  1022â†’
  1023â†’| From | Can Import To |
  1024â†’|------|---------------|
  1025â†’| features/ | shared/, features/[same feature] |
  1026â†’| shared/ | shared/ only |
  1027â†’| app/ | features/, shared/ |
  1028â†’
  1029â†’**Import Aliases (no relative imports):**
  1030â†’- `@shared/*` â†’ `src/shared/*`
  1031â†’- `@features/*` â†’ `src/features/*`
  1032â†’- `@app/*` â†’ `src/app/*`
  1033â†’- `@/*` â†’ `src/*`
  1034â†’
  1035â†’### Why Feature-Based Architecture?
  1036â†’
  1037â†’| Benefit | Description |
  1038â†’|---------|-------------|
  1039â†’| **Isolation** | Features can't accidentally depend on each other |
  1040â†’| **Merge Safety** | Multiple developers can work on different features |
  1041â†’| **Clear Boundaries** | ESLint enforces boundaries at compile time |
  1042â†’| **Easy Deletion** | Delete a feature folder, nothing breaks |
  1043â†’| **Testability** | Features can be tested independently |

  1047â†’## Quality Hooks

  1062â†’  âœ… File size >300 lines  â†’ Needs modularization
  1063â†’  âœ… Direct API calls      â†’ Should use data layer
  1064â†’  âœ… UI duplication        â†’ Should use @shared/ui
  1065â†’  âœ… Exposed secrets       â†’ Security risk
  1066â†’  âœ… Auth file changes     â†’ Security review needed

  1071â†’**File:** `.claude/hooks/stop-comprehensive-check.sh`

  1073â†’**Runs:** Before completing work

  1075â†’```bash

  1084â†’Output:

  1088â†’```

  1090â†’### Zero Tolerance Rules
  1091â†’
  1092â†’The following violations will BLOCK commits:
  1093â†’
  1094â†’1. **'any' Types - ZERO TOLERANCE**
  1095â†’   - No `: any`, `: any[]`, `<any>`, `Promise<any>`
  1096â†’   - Use proper interfaces or `unknown` with type guards
  1097â†’
  1098â†’2. **Gradients in CSS - ZERO TOLERANCE**
  1099â†’   - No `linear-gradient`, `radial-gradient`, `conic-gradient`
  1100â†’   - Use solid professional colors only
  1101â†’
  1102â†’3. **Emojis in UI - ZERO TOLERANCE**
  1103â†’   - No emojis anywhere in UI components
  1104â†’   - Use professional icon libraries (lucide-react, heroicons)
  1105â†’
  1106â†’4. **Relative Imports**
  1107â†’   - No `import { Foo } from './foo'` or `../bar`
  1108â†’   - Use `@/` aliases for all imports

    10â†’---

    30â†’## STEP 2: Extract Features from Message (if no plan.md)
    31â†’
    32â†’**Analyze the user's message** to identify:

    52â†’## STEP 2.5: LOAD EXISTING CONTEXT (MEMORY AWARENESS)

     6â†’# Maven Flow PRD Converter

     8â†’Convert markdown PRD files to JSON format for Maven Flow processing.

    15â†’## Commands

   102â†’### Key JSON Fields

   131â†’## Related PRD Detection
   132â†’
   133â†’The converter intelligently detects related PRDs by analyzing:
   134â†’
   135â†’### 1. Feature Dependencies
   136â†’- **Authentication PRD**: Auto-detected when stories mention:
   137â†’  - "user", "login", "signup", "auth", "session"
   138â†’  - Protected routes, permissions
   139â†’- **Database PRD**: Auto-detected when stories mention:
   140â†’  - "table", "schema", "migration", "database"
   141â†’  - Supabase, PostgreSQL
   142â†’
   143â†’### 2. Naming Patterns
   144â†’Scans `docs/prd-*.md` files for similar keywords:
   145â†’- "dashboard" relates to "authentication" (requires auth)
   146â†’- "tasks" relates to "users" (has user_id foreign key)
   147â†’- "notifications" relates to "users" (sends to users)
   148â†’
   149â†’### 3. Integration Points
   150â†’- Features that share database tables
   151â†’- Features with API dependencies
   152â†’- UI components that reference other features
   153â†’
   154â†’### Related PRD Example
   155â†’
   156â†’**Dashboard PRD (depends on Authentication):**
   157â†’```json

   159â†’  "schemaVersion": 1,
   160â†’  "project": "User Dashboard",
   161â†’  "consolidatedMemory": "docs/consolidated-dashboard.txt",
   162â†’  "relatedPRDs": ["docs/prd-authentication.json"],
   163â†’  ...
   164â†’}
   165â†’```
   166â†’
   167â†’- Dashboard's `consolidatedMemory` points to ITS OWN memory
   168â†’- Dashboard's `relatedPRDs` points to Authentication PRD

   172â†’## Conversion Rules
   173â†’
   174â†’### 1. Boolean Status Fields
   175â†’
   176â†’**Markdown Status Field** (informational for humans):
   177â†’```markdown
   178â†’**Status:** false (informational - for humans)
   179â†’```
   180â†’
   181â†’**JSON passes Field** (authoritative for machines):
   182â†’```json
   183â†’"passes": false
   184â†’```
   185â†’
   186â†’- Use `true`/`false` (boolean), NOT "complete"/"incomplete"
   187â†’- The JSON `passes` field is the authoritative source
   188â†’- Markdown status is informational only
   189â†’
   190â†’### 2. Memory References
   191â†’
   192â†’**consolidatedMemory** (points to THIS PRD's memory):
   193â†’```json
   194â†’"consolidatedMemory": "docs/consolidated-[feature].txt"

   196â†’
   197â†’- Always points to THIS PRD's OWN consolidated memory
   198â†’- Will be created AFTER all stories complete
   199â†’- Used by OTHER PRDs that depend on this one
   200â†’
   201â†’**relatedPRDs** (points to OTHER PRDs):
   202â†’```json
   203â†’"relatedPRDs": ["docs/prd-authentication.json"]
   204â†’```
   205â†’
   206â†’- Array of OTHER PRD JSON files
   207â†’- Used to load their consolidated memories
   208â†’- Enables cross-PRD context sharing
   209â†’
   210â†’### 3. MCP Tools Mapping
   211â†’
   212â†’Each step can specify different MCP tools:
   213â†’
   214â†’```json
   215â†’"mcpTools": {
   216â†’  "step1": ["supabase"],
   217â†’  "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"],
   218â†’  "step10": []

   221â†’
   222â†’- `step1`: Use supabase MCP
   223â†’- `step7`: Use supabase AND web-search-prime MCPs
   224â†’- `step10`: No specific MCPs required

   609â†’### `/flow start [max-iterations]`
   610â†’Starts autonomous flow execution.
   611â†’
   612â†’**Parameters:**
   613â†’- `max-iterations` (optional): Number of stories to process (default: 10)
   614â†’

   616â†’- Scans for all PRD files in `docs/`
   617â†’- Identifies incomplete stories (`passes: false`)
   618â†’- Processes stories in priority order
   619â†’- Spawns specialist agents for each mavenStep
   620â†’- Runs quality checks after each story
   621â†’- Commits changes with standardized format
   622â†’- Updates PRD to mark story complete
   623â†’- Continues to next story automatically
   624â†’
   625â†’**Examples:**
   626â†’```bash

   644â†’   - Marks story as complete in PRD
   645â†’5. Moves to next story automatically
   646â†’6. Continues until max iterations or all PRDs complete

   916â†’## MCP Tool Assignment
   917â†’
   918â†’### What are MCPs?
   919â†’MCPs (Model Context Protocol) extend Claude with external tools like databases, web search, and browser automation.
   920â†’
   921â†’### How MCP Assignment Works
   922â†’
   923â†’**1. PRD specifies MCPs per step:**
   924â†’```json
   925â†’{
   926â†’  "id": "US-001",
   927â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   928â†’  "mcpTools": {
   929â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   930â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   931â†’  }
   932â†’}
   933â†’```
   934â†’
   935â†’**2. Flow tells agent which MCPs to use:**
   936â†’```
   937â†’*** CRITICAL: MCP TOOLS INSTRUCTION ***
   938â†’You MUST use the Supabase MCP tools for ALL database operations.
   939â†’SCAN FIRST - Use MCP to list/check what exists in the database BEFORE making changes.
   940â†’Query the database DIRECTLY using Supabase MCP tools.
   941â†’
   942â†’Story: US-001, Step 1
   943â†’MCPs: supabase
   944â†’```
   945â†’
   946â†’**3. Agent uses those MCPs:**
   947â†’- Checks if MCPs are available in their tool set
   948â†’- Uses MCP tools directly to query database, run migrations, etc.
   949â†’- Falls back to standard tools only if MCPs unavailable
   950â†’
   951â†’### Available MCPs

   964â†’**MCP Usage Rules:**
   965â†’- **SCAN FIRST** - Always list/check what exists before making changes

  1001â†’
  1002â†’1. **Create PRD** - Use the `flow-prd` skill to generate requirements
  1003â†’2. **Convert to JSON** - Use the `flow-convert` skill to create `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`
  1004â†’3. **Start Flow** - Run `/flow start` to begin autonomous iteration
  1005â†’4. **Monitor Progress** - Use `/flow status` to check all PRDs
  1006â†’5. **Review Results** - Each story is committed separately with descriptive messages

  1008â†’## How It Works
  1009â†’
  1010â†’### Multi-PRD Processing
  1011â†’
  1012â†’When you run `/flow start`:
  1013â†’
  1014â†’1. **Scan Phase:** The flow scans `docs/` for all `prd-*.json` files
  1015â†’2. **Priority Phase:** For each PRD, checks completion status:
  1016â†’   - Loads JSON and checks if all stories have `passes: true`
  1017â†’   - Identifies PRDs with incomplete stories (`passes: false`)
  1018â†’3. **Selection Phase:** Picks the first incomplete PRD (alphabetically by filename)
  1019â†’4. **Iteration Phase:** Processes that PRD's stories one by one:
  1020â†’   - Reads PRD JSON and picks highest priority story where `passes: false`
  1021â†’   - Reads story's `mavenSteps` array
  1022â†’   - **Spawns specialist agents directly** (one per mavenStep)
  1023â†’   - Waits for each agent to complete
  1024â†’   - Runs quality checks
  1025â†’   - Commits changes
  1026â†’   - Updates PRD to `passes: true`
  1027â†’   - Appends learnings to progress file
  1028â†’5. **Completion Phase:** When PRD is complete (all `passes: true`):
  1029â†’   - Marks PRD as complete
  1030â†’   - Moves to next incomplete PRD
  1031â†’   - Repeats iteration phase
  1032â†’6. **Final Phase:** When all PRDs are complete:
  1033â†’   - Outputs completion summary
  1034â†’

  1140â†’## Feature-Based Architecture
  1141â†’
  1142â†’Maven Flow enforces this structure for all new code:
  1143â†’
  1144â†’```
  1145â†’src/
  1146â†’â”œâ”€â”€ app/                    # Entry points, routing
  1147â†’â”œâ”€â”€ features/               # Isolated feature modules
  1148â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ auth/              # Cannot import from other features
  1149â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ dashboard/
  1150â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [feature-name]/
  1151â†’â”œâ”€â”€ shared/                # Shared code (no feature imports)
  1152â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ui/                # Reusable components
  1153â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ api/               # Backend clients
  1154â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ utils/             # Utilities
  1155â†’```

  1157â†’**Architecture Rules:**
  1158â†’- Features â†’ Cannot import from other features
  1159â†’- Features â†’ Can import from shared/
  1160â†’- Shared â†’ Cannot import from features
  1161â†’- Use `@shared/*`, `@features/*`, `@app/*` aliases (no relative imports)

  1293â†’## Required MCPs
  1294â†’
  1295â†’### Mandatory MCPs for Maven Flow
  1296â†’
  1297â†’Maven Flow requires specific MCP servers to be configured for autonomous development and testing to function correctly.
  1298â†’
  1299â†’#### Two Mandatory MCPs
  1300â†’
  1301â†’**1. Supabase MCP (MANDATORY)**
  1302â†’- **Purpose:** Direct database access, schema verification, migrations, type generation
  1303â†’- **Why mandatory:**
  1304â†’  - Agents need to QUERY the actual database (not read files)
  1305â†’  - Agents need to VERIFY tables and schema exist
  1306â†’  - Agents need to CREATE tables and run migrations
  1307â†’  - Agents need to GENERATE TypeScript types from live schema
  1308â†’- **Without Supabase MCP:**
  1309â†’  - Agents will fall back to reading migration files (doesn't verify actual database)
  1310â†’  - Agents will create migration scripts manually (error-prone)
  1311â†’  - Agents cannot verify what's actually in the database
  1312â†’
  1313â†’**2. chrome-devtools MCP (MANDATORY)**
  1314â†’- **Purpose:** Live browser testing, console log reading, application verification
  1315â†’- **Why mandatory:**
  1316â†’  - testing-agent MUST open the application to test features
  1317â†’  - Agents MUST read console logs to find errors
  1318â†’  - Agents MUST verify UI works in real browser
  1319â†’  - Agents MUST test user flows end-to-end
  1320â†’- **Without chrome-devtools MCP:**
  1321â†’  - testing-agent cannot test the application
  1322â†’  - Console errors go undetected
  1323â†’  - Features cannot be verified in browser
  1324â†’  - Testing becomes manual and incomplete
  1325â†’
  1326â†’#### How to Verify MCPs Are Configured
  1327â†’
  1328â†’**Before running `/flow start`:**
  1329â†’
  1330â†’1. **Check Claude Code MCP Settings:**
  1331â†’   - Open Claude Code Settings
  1332â†’   - Go to MCP Servers section
  1333â†’   - Verify "supabase" is in the list
  1334â†’   - Verify "chrome-devtools" is in the list
  1335â†’
  1336â†’2. **Test MCPs are working:**
  1337â†’   - Start a conversation
  1338â†’   - Ask agent to list tables using Supabase MCP
  1339â†’   - Ask agent to open browser using chrome-devtools MCP
  1340â†’
  1341â†’3. **If MCPs are missing:**
  1342â†’   - DO NOT start `/flow start`

  1363â†’#### Summary
  1364â†’
  1365â†’**MANDATORY MCPs (Must Have):**

  1379â†’## Testing & Consolidation
  1380â†’
  1381â†’### Workflow: Test â†’ Log â†’ Consolidate â†’ Fix
  1382â†’
  1383â†’Maven Flow includes a systematic testing and error consolidation workflow to ensure quality.
  1384â†’
  1385â†’### Step 1: Test (`/flow test`)
  1386â†’
  1387â†’**Purpose:** Comprehensive automated testing of all completed features
  1388â†’
  1389â†’**What happens:**
  1390â†’1. Reads PRD to find completed stories (where `passes: true`)
  1391â†’2. Starts dev server: `pnpm dev`
  1392â†’3. Opens application using chrome-devtools MCP
  1393â†’4. Tests user signup/login with standard test credentials
  1394â†’5. Tests each completed feature's acceptance criteria
  1395â†’6. Checks console for errors (logs ALL errors found)
  1396â†’7. Tests navigation, forms, data display
  1397â†’8. Creates error log at `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
  1398â†’
  1399â†’**Standard Test User:**
  1400â†’- Email: `revccnt@gmail.com`
  1401â†’- Password: `Elishiba!90`
  1402â†’
  1403â†’**What gets tested:**
  1404â†’- User authentication (signup, login, logout)
  1405â†’- All completed stories' acceptance criteria
  1406â†’- Console errors (JavaScript, network, API)
  1407â†’- UI functionality
  1408â†’- Navigation between pages
  1409â†’- Form submissions
  1410â†’- Data display
  1411â†’
  1412â†’**Example:**
  1413â†’```bash
  1414â†’/flow test task-priority
  1415â†’```
  1416â†’
  1417â†’**Output:**
  1418â†’- Shows which features are being tested
  1419â†’- Reports errors in real-time
  1420â†’- Creates error log markdown file
  1421â†’- Summary with error counts by severity
  1422â†’
  1423â†’### Step 2: Review Error Log
  1424â†’
  1425â†’**Error log format:** `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
  1426â†’
  1427â†’**Each error includes:**
  1428â†’- Story ID (US-XXX)
  1429â†’- Severity (Critical / High / Medium / Low)
  1430â†’- Error type (Console Error / Network Error / UI Issue)
  1431â†’- Error message (exact text from console)
  1432â†’- Steps to reproduce
  1433â†’- Expected vs actual behavior
  1434â†’- Related file references
  1435â†’- Suggested fixes
  1436â†’
  1437â†’**Example error log entry:**
  1438â†’```markdown
  1439â†’## Error 1
  1440â†’
  1441â†’**Story:** US-003 - Add priority selector
  1442â†’**Feature:** Task creation form
  1443â†’**Severity:** High
  1444â†’
  1445â†’**Error Type:** Console Error
  1446â†’
  1447â†’**Error Message:**
  1448â†’```
  1449â†’Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'map' of undefined
  1450â†’at PrioritySelector.tsx:24
  1451â†’```
  1452â†’
  1453â†’**Steps to Reproduce:**
  1454â†’1. Navigate to /tasks/create
  1455â†’2. Click on "Priority" dropdown
  1456â†’3. Observe error in console
  1457â†’
  1458â†’**Expected Behavior:**
  1459â†’Priority dropdown shows options: Low, Medium, High, Urgent
  1460â†’
  1461â†’**Actual Behavior:**
  1462â†’Application crashes, dropdown doesn't render
  1463â†’
  1464â†’**Related Files:**
  1465â†’- File: src/features/tasks/components/PrioritySelector.tsx
  1466â†’- Line: 24
  1467â†’- Component: PrioritySelector
  1468â†’
  1469â†’**Suggested Fix:**
  1470â†’Check that priorities prop is defined before mapping. Add default value or null check.
  1471â†’```
  1472â†’
  1473â†’### Step 3: Consolidate (`/flow consolidate`)
  1474â†’
  1475â†’**Purpose:** Fix ONLY the specific errors found during testing (NOT reimplement features)
  1476â†’
  1477â†’**What happens:**
  1478â†’1. Reads error log from `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
  1479â†’2. Parses each error to identify:
  1480â†’   - Which story (US-XXX) has the error
  1481â†’   - Which step/mavenStep needs to be re-run
  1482â†’   - What the specific error is
  1483â†’3. For each error:
  1484â†’   - Spawns appropriate specialist agent (development, quality, security, etc.)
  1485â†’   - Tells agent exactly what error to fix
  1486â†’   - Waits for fix to be applied
  1487â†’4. Re-tests ONLY the fixed item
  1488â†’5. Marks error as resolved in log
  1489â†’6. Continues until all errors fixed
  1490â†’
  1491â†’**What it does NOT do:**
  1492â†’- Does NOT run full mavenSteps again
  1493â†’- Does NOT re-implement completed features
  1494â†’- Does NOT touch working code
  1495â†’- Only fixes the specific errors identified
  1496â†’
  1497â†’**Example:**
  1498â†’```bash
  1499â†’/flow consolidate task-priority
  1500â†’```
  1501â†’
  1502â†’**Output:**
  1503â†’- Shows which errors are being fixed
  1504â†’- Shows which agent is handling each fix
  1505â†’- Commits each fix separately
  1506â†’- Updates error log as fixes are applied
  1507â†’
  1508â†’### Step 4: Re-test
  1509â†’
  1510â†’After consolidation:
  1511â†’1. Run `/flow test [prd-name]` again
  1512â†’2. Verify all errors are fixed
  1513â†’3. Verify console is clean
  1514â†’4. If errors remain, repeat consolidation
  1515â†’
  1516â†’### Complete Workflow Example
  1517â†’
  1518â†’```bash
  1519â†’# 1. Run development flow
  1520â†’/flow start
  1521â†’
  1522â†’# 2. Test all completed features
  1523â†’/flow test task-priority
  1524â†’
  1525â†’# Output: Testing Complete
  1526â†’# Error Log: docs/errors-task-priority.md
  1527â†’# Total Errors: 5
  1528â†’# Critical: 1 | High: 2 | Medium: 1 | Low: 1
  1529â†’
  1530â†’# 3. Review error log
  1531â†’cat docs/errors-task-priority.md
  1532â†’
  1533â†’# 4. Fix all errors
  1534â†’/flow consolidate task-priority
  1535â†’
  1536â†’# Output:
  1537â†’# Fixing Error 1: TypeError in PrioritySelector
  1538â†’# Spawning quality-agent...
  1539â†’# â†’ Fixed
  1540â†’# Fixing Error 2: Network error in API
  1541â†’# Spawning development-agent...
  1542â†’# â†’ Fixed
  1543â†’# ...
  1544â†’
  1545â†’# 5. Re-test to verify
  1546â†’/flow test task-priority
  1547â†’
  1548â†’# Output: Testing Complete
  1549â†’# Total Errors: 0
  1550â†’# âœ… All features working correctly
  1551â†’```
  1552â†’
  1553â†’### Key Differences: `/flow start` vs `/flow consolidate`
  1554â†’
  1555â†’| Aspect | `/flow start` | `/flow consolidate` |
  1556â†’|--------|---------------|---------------------|
  1557â†’| Purpose | Implement new features | Fix specific errors |
  1558â†’| Input | PRD stories | Error log |
  1559â†’| Runs | Full mavenSteps for each story | Only affected steps |
  1560â†’| Scope | Entire story implementation | Specific error fixes |
  1561â†’| Commits | Full feature commits | Targeted bug fixes |
  1562â†’| Result | New features implemented | Errors resolved |

  1632â†’### Mobile-Specific Features
  1633â†’
  1634â†’#### Offline-First Architecture
  1635â†’All mobile features work offline with automatic sync:
  1636â†’
  1637â†’**Read Pattern:**
  1638â†’1. Check AsyncStorage cache first
  1639â†’2. If fresh (< 5 min), use cached data
  1640â†’3. If missing/stale, fetch from Supabase
  1641â†’4. Update cache and display
  1642â†’
  1643â†’**Write Pattern:**
  1644â†’1. Optimistically update UI immediately
  1645â†’2. If online: Execute immediately
  1646â†’3. If offline: Queue in AsyncStorage
  1647â†’4. When back online: Process queue automatically
  1648â†’
  1649â†’#### Native UI Patterns
  1650â†’Use mobile-specific interactions:
  1651â†’- **Pull-to-refresh** for data reload
  1652â†’- **Swipe actions** for quick actions (delete, complete)
  1653â†’- **Bottom sheets** for options/modals
  1654â†’- **Tab bar** for main navigation
  1655â†’- **Stack navigation** for drilling down
  1656â†’- **Long-press** for context menus
  1657â†’
  1658â†’#### Touch Targets
  1659â†’- **Minimum 44x44 points** for all touch targets (Apple)
  1660â†’- **48x48 dp minimum** for Android
  1661â†’- Adequate spacing between targets
  1662â†’
  1663â†’#### Push Notifications

  1665â†’- Task assignments, due reminders, status changes
  1666â†’- Background message handling
  1667â†’- Notification channels (Android)

  2375â†’## Folder Creation and Memory Management
  2376â†’
  2377â†’### Automatic Folder Creation
  2378â†’
  2379â†’The flow automatically creates the `docs/[feature]/` folder when processing the first story of a PRD:
  2380â†’
  2381â†’```bash
  2382â†’# First story of authentication PRD
  2383â†’docs/authentication/                    # Auto-created
  2384â†’â”œâ”€â”€ story-US-001-login.txt            # Created after US-001 complete

  2386â†’â””â”€â”€ story-US-003-reset-password.txt   # Created after US-003 complete
  2387â†’```
  2388â†’
  2389â†’### Memory File Updates
  2390â†’
  2391â†’When a story is re-run (e.g., after consolidation):
  2392â†’1. Read existing memory file
  2393â†’2. Append new learnings
  2394â†’3. Update `memoryVersion` if format changes
  2395â†’4. Keep full history of iterations
  2396â†’
  2397â†’### Memory Versioning
  2398â†’
  2399â†’Each memory file includes version info for future compatibility:
  2400â†’
  2401â†’```yaml

  2403â†’memoryVersion: 1
  2404â†’schemaVersion: 1
  2405â†’---
  2406â†’```
  2407â†’
  2408â†’**Benefits:**
  2409â†’- System evolution: Old memories won't be misinterpreted
  2410â†’- Backward compatibility: Agents can adapt behavior based on version
  2411â†’- Migration support: Clear path for upgrading memory formats
  2412â†’- Debugging: Version mismatches immediately visible

  2415â†’
  2416â†’## Terminal Command Integration
  2417â†’
  2418â†’The terminal forwarder scripts (`bin/flow.sh`, `bin/flow-prd.sh`, `bin/flow-convert.sh`) invoke these Claude Code commands directly.
  2419â†’
  2420â†’**Terminal â†’ Claude Code mapping:**
  2421â†’```bash
  2422â†’flow start           â†’ /flow start
  2423â†’flow status          â†’ /flow status
  2424â†’flow-prd create ...  â†’ /flow-prd create ...
  2425â†’flow-convert auth    â†’ /flow-convert auth
  2426â†’```
  2427â†’
  2428â†’The terminal scripts are minimal - they just forward user input to Claude Code which handles all the actual work.
  2429â†’

  2431â†’
  2432â†’## Help
  2433â†’
  2434â†’### `/flow help`
  2435â†’
  2436â†’Displays comprehensive help information for Maven Flow.
  2437â†’
  2438â†’```bash
  2439â†’/flow help
  2440â†’flow help
  2441â†’```
  2442â†’
  2443â†’### Quick Reference
  2444â†’
  2445â†’| Command | Description | Usage |
  2446â†’|---------|-------------|-------|
  2447â†’| `start [n]` | Start autonomous development | `flow start 10` |
  2448â†’| `status` | Show progress across all PRDs | `flow status` |
  2449â†’| `continue [prd] [n]` | Resume from last iteration | `flow continue auth 5` |
  2450â†’| `reset [prd]` | Archive and reset a PRD | `flow reset auth` |
  2451â†’| `test [prd]` | Test implemented features | `flow test auth` |
  2452â†’| `consolidate [prd]` | Fix errors from testing | `flow consolidate auth` |
  2453â†’| `help` | Show this help | `flow help` |
  2454â†’
  2455â†’### Memory System Overview
  2456â†’
  2457â†’Maven Flow uses a three-layer memory ecosystem:
  2458â†’
  2459â†’1. **Story Memory** (`docs/[feature]/story-US-[###]-[title].txt`)
  2460â†’   - Created after each story completes
  2461â†’   - Contains: implemented, decisions, challenges, lessons
  2462â†’
  2463â†’2. **Consolidated Memory** (`docs/consolidated-[feature].txt`)
  2464â†’   - Created when ALL stories in PRD complete
  2465â†’   - Aggressively summarized to ~30-50K tokens
  2466â†’   - Contains: architecture, interfaces, integration patterns
  2467â†’
  2468â†’3. **Cross-PRD Context** (assembled dynamically)
  2469â†’   - Related PRD summaries (~3-5K tokens per PRD)
  2470â†’   - Previous story summaries (~10K tokens total)
  2471â†’   - Assembled before spawning agents
  2472â†’
  2473â†’### Feature Relationships
  2474â†’
  2475â†’PRDs can have relationships with other PRDs:
  2476â†’
  2477â†’| Type | Description | Example |
  2478â†’|------|-------------|---------|
  2479â†’| `depends_on` | This PRD depends on another | Payments â†’ Authentication |
  2480â†’| `depended_by` | Another PRD depends on this | Payments â† Orders |
  2481â†’| `bidirectional` | Mutual dependency (rare) | Auth â†” Profiles |
  2482â†’
  2483â†’### Maven Steps
  2484â†’
  2485â†’Each story specifies which Maven steps to execute:
  2486â†’
  2487â†’| Step | Agent | Description |
  2488â†’|------|-------|-------------|
  2489â†’| 1 | development | Foundation - Import UI or create from scratch |
  2490â†’| 2 | development | Package Manager - Convert npm â†’ pnpm |
  2491â†’| 3 | refactor | Feature Structure - Feature-based folders |
  2492â†’| 4 | refactor | Modularization - Split components >300 lines |
  2493â†’| 5 | quality | Type Safety - No 'any' types, @ aliases |
  2494â†’| 6 | refactor | UI Centralization - Move to @shared/ui |
  2495â†’| 7 | development | Data Layer - Backend setup, Supabase |
  2496â†’| 8 | security | Auth Integration - Firebase + Supabase |
  2497â†’| 9 | development | MCP Integration - Connect MCP tools |
  2498â†’| 10 | security | Security & Error Handling |
  2499â†’| 11 | design | Mobile Design - Professional UI (optional) |
  2500â†’
  2501â†’### MCP Tools
  2502â†’
  2503â†’MCPs (Model Context Protocol) are assigned per step:
  2504â†’
  2505â†’```json
  2506â†’{
  2507â†’  "mcpTools": {
  2508â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
  2509â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
  2510â†’  }
  2511â†’}
  2512â†’```
  2513â†’
  2514â†’**Common MCPs:**
  2515â†’- `supabase` - Database operations (steps 1, 7, 8, 10)
  2516â†’- `chrome-devtools` - Browser testing (testing phases)
  2517â†’- `web-search-prime` - Research, documentation (all steps)
  2518â†’- `web-reader` - Read web content (all steps)
  2519â†’
  2520â†’### Quality Standards
  2521â†’
  2522â†’**Zero Tolerance Rules:**
  2523â†’
  2524â†’1. **'any' Types - ZERO TOLERANCE**
  2525â†’   - No `: any`, `: any[]`, `<any>`, `Promise<any>`
  2526â†’   - Use proper interfaces or `unknown` with type guards
  2527â†’
  2528â†’2. **Gradients in CSS - ZERO TOLERANCE**
  2529â†’   - No `linear-gradient`, `radial-gradient`, `conic-gradient`
  2530â†’   - Use solid professional colors only
  2531â†’
  2532â†’3. **Emojis in UI - ZERO TOLERANCE**
  2533â†’   - No emojis anywhere in UI components
  2534â†’   - Use professional icon libraries (lucide-react, heroicons)
  2535â†’
  2536â†’4. **Relative Imports**
  2537â†’   - No `import { Foo } from './foo'` or `../bar`
  2538â†’   - Use `@/` aliases for all imports
  2539â†’
  2540â†’### File Structure
  2541â†’
  2542â†’```
  2543â†’docs/
  2544â†’â”œâ”€â”€ [feature]/                          # Story memories folder
  2545â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ story-US-001-[title].txt       # Story: US-001
  2546â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ story-US-002-[title].txt       # Story: US-002
  2547â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prd-[feature].md                   # Human-readable PRD
  2548â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prd-[feature].json                 # Machine-readable PRD
  2549â†’â”œâ”€â”€ consolidated-[feature].txt          # Consolidated memory
  2550â†’â””â”€â”€ progress-[feature].txt             # Progress log
  2551â†’```
  2552â†’
  2553â†’### Common Workflows
  2554â†’
  2555â†’**New Feature:**
  2556â†’```bash
  2557â†’1. flow-prd create "feature description"
  2558â†’2. flow-convert feature
  2559â†’3. flow start
  2560â†’4. flow status
  2561â†’```
  2562â†’
  2563â†’**Resume After Error:**
  2564â†’```bash
  2565â†’1. Fix the error
  2566â†’2. flow continue
  2567â†’```
  2568â†’
  2569â†’**Test Implementation:**
  2570â†’```bash
  2571â†’1. flow test [prd]
  2572â†’2. Review docs/errors-[prd].md
  2573â†’3. flow consolidate [prd]
  2574â†’```
  2575â†’
  2576â†’**Start Fresh:**
  2577â†’```bash
  2578â†’1. flow reset [prd]
  2579â†’2. flow start
  2580â†’```
  2581â†’
  2582â†’### Getting More Help
  2583â†’
  2584â†’**For specific topics:**
  2585â†’- PRD Creation: See `.claude/commands/flow-prd.md`
  2586â†’- PRD Conversion: See `.claude/skills/flow-convert/SKILL.md`
  2587â†’- Terminal Scripts: See `bin/README.md`
  2588â†’- Memory System: See main `README.md`
  2589â†’
  2590â†’**For troubleshooting:**
  2591â†’- Run `flow status` for diagnostics
  2592â†’- Check progress file: `docs/progress-[feature].txt`

    49â†’## The 10-Step Workflow

   138â†’### Step 5: Type Safety & Import Aliases

   165â†’### Step 6: Centralized UI Components

     5â†’## JSON Structure

    12â†’  "memorialFile": "string - Path to memorial file: docs/memorial-feature-name.txt",
    13â†’  "relatedMemorials": [

    15â†’  ],

    18â†’      "id": "string - User story ID: US-001, US-002, etc.",
    19â†’      "title": "string - Short title describing the story",
    20â†’      "description": "string - Full user story: As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]",
    21â†’      "acceptanceCriteria": [

    39â†’## Field Specifications
    40â†’
    41â†’### Root Level
    42â†’
    43â†’| Field | Type | Required | Description |
    44â†’|-------|------|----------|-------------|
    45â†’| `project` | string | Yes | Project name, typically from PRD title |
    46â†’| `branchName` | string | Yes | Git branch name for this feature (format: `flow/feature-name`) |
    47â†’| `description` | string | Yes | One-line summary of what this feature does |
    48â†’| `memorialFile` | string | Yes | Path to this feature's memorial file |
    49â†’| `relatedMemorials` | array | Yes | List of related memorial file paths |
    50â†’| `userStories` | array | Yes | Array of user story objects (minimum 1) |
    51â†’
    52â†’### User Story Object
    53â†’
    54â†’| Field | Type | Required | Description |
    55â†’|-------|------|----------|-------------|
    56â†’| `id` | string | Yes | Story identifier: US-001, US-002, etc. |
    57â†’| `title` | string | Yes | Short descriptive title |
    58â†’| `description` | string | Yes | Full user story format: "As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]" |
    59â†’| `acceptanceCriteria` | array | Yes | List of verifiable criteria. Must include "Typecheck passes" |
    60â†’| `mavenSteps` | array | Yes | Array of step numbers (1-10). Never empty. |
    61â†’| `mcpTools` | object | Yes | Step-based MCP tool mapping. Use `{}` if none. |
    62â†’| `priority` | number | Yes | Priority order (lower = higher priority). Must be â‰¥ 1. |
    63â†’| `passes` | boolean | Yes | Story completion status. Always `false` initially. |
    64â†’| `notes` | string | Yes | Implementation notes. Always empty string initially. |

    66â†’## Maven Steps Reference
    67â†’
    68â†’Every user story must specify which Maven Flow steps are required:
    69â†’
    70â†’| Step | Agent | Purpose |
    71â†’|------|-------|---------|
    72â†’| 1 | development | Foundation/UI from scratch |
    73â†’| 2 | development | Package manager changes (npmâ†’pnpm) |
    74â†’| 3 | refactor | Feature structure changes |
    75â†’| 4 | refactor | Modularization (when >300 lines) |
    76â†’| 5 | quality | Type safety enforcement (no 'any' types) |
    77â†’| 6 | refactor | UI centralization (@shared/ui) |
    78â†’| 7 | development | Data layer/backend implementation |
    79â†’| 8 | security | Authentication/authorization integration |
    80â†’| 9 | development | MCP integration |
    81â†’| 10 | security | Security hardening & error handling |
    82â†’
    83â†’### Step Mapping by Story Type
    84â†’
    85â†’- **Database changes** â†’ `[1, 7]`
    86â†’- **UI component** â†’ `[5, 6]`
    87â†’- **Backend API** â†’ `[1, 7, 10]`
    88â†’- **Auth flow** â†’ `[1, 7, 8, 10]`
    89â†’- **Full feature** â†’ `[1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 10]`
    90â†’
    91â†’## MCP Tools Format
    92â†’
    93â†’The `mcpTools` object maps step numbers to MCP server names:
    94â†’
    95â†’```json
    96â†’{
    97â†’  "mcpTools": {
    98â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
    99â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   100â†’  }
   101â†’}
   102â†’```
   103â†’
   104â†’**Rules:**
   105â†’- Only list MCP **server names** (e.g., "supabase"), not individual tools
   106â†’- Use step-based keys: "step1", "step2", etc.
   107â†’- Use empty object `{}` if no MCPs needed for this story
   108â†’
   109â†’### Common MCPs
   110â†’
   111â†’| MCP Name | When to Use |
   112â†’|----------|-------------|
   113â†’| `supabase` | Steps 1, 7, 8, 10 - Database/auth operations |
   114â†’| `web-search-prime` | All steps - Web searches |
   115â†’| `chrome-devtools` | Testing - Browser automation |
   116â†’| `4-5v-mcp` | All steps - Image analysis |
   117â†’
   118â†’## Story Sizing Rules
   119â†’
   120â†’Each story MUST be completable in ONE iteration (one context window).
   121â†’
   122â†’### RIGHT-sized stories:
   123â†’- Add database column + migration
   124â†’- Add UI component to existing page
   125â†’- Update server action with new logic
   126â†’- Implement single API endpoint
   127â†’
   128â†’### TOO BIG (split these):
   129â†’- "Build entire dashboard" â†’ Split into: schema, queries, UI, filters
   130â†’- "Add authentication" â†’ Split into: schema, middleware, login UI, sessions
   131â†’- "Create CRUD system" â†’ Split into: Create, Read, Update, Delete separately
   132â†’
   133â†’## Story Ordering
   134â†’
   135â†’Stories should be ordered by dependency:
   136â†’
   137â†’1. **Schema/database changes** (foundational)
   138â†’2. **Server actions/backend logic** (depend on schema)
   139â†’3. **UI components** (depend on backend)
   140â†’4. **Dashboard/summary views** (depend on everything)
   141â†’
   142â†’## Acceptance Criteria Rules
   143â†’
   144â†’All criteria must be **verifiable**:
   145â†’
   146â†’âœ“ Good: "Add status column with default 'pending'"
   147â†’âœ“ Good: "Redirect unauthenticated users to /login"
   148â†’âœ“ Good: "Typecheck passes"
   149â†’
   150â†’âœ— Bad: "Works correctly"
   151â†’âœ— Bad: "User friendly interface"
   152â†’âœ— Bad: "Error handling"
   153â†’
   154â†’**Required:** Every story MUST include `"Typecheck passes"` in acceptance criteria.

   231â†’These files are generated from `prd-{feature-name}.md` markdown PRDs.

     6â†’# Flow PRD Converter with Memory Loading

     8â†’Converts existing PRDs (markdown) to the `prd.json` format that next-mavens-flow uses for autonomous execution.
     9â†’
    10â†’**NEW: Now loads existing context and analyzes feature relationships.**
    11â†’
    12â†’---
    13â†’
    14â†’## The Job
    15â†’
    16â†’Take a markdown PRD and convert it to `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`. Create `docs/` folder if it doesn't exist.
    17â†’
    18â†’**Important:** Each feature gets its own PRD JSON file. The flow command will scan for all `prd-*.json` files in `docs/` and process incomplete ones.
    19â†’
    20â†’**CRITICAL:** Each story MUST have its own `mcpTools` object specifying which MCPs to use for each Maven step.
    21â†’
    22â†’---
    23â†’
    24â†’## STEP 1: Read the Markdown PRD
    25â†’
    26â†’**Read the input PRD file:**
    27â†’
    28â†’Execute: `cat "$PRD_FILE"`
    29â†’
    30â†’**Extract key information:**
    31â†’- Project name
    32â†’- Branch name
    33â†’- Description
    34â†’- User stories
    35â†’- Related features (from flow-prd.md Step 2.6)
    36â†’- Context from existing features (if included)
    37â†’
    38â†’---
    39â†’
    40â†’## STEP 2: SCAN EXISTING JSON PRDs
    41â†’
    42â†’**CRITICAL: Before creating the JSON PRD, scan for existing PRDs to understand relationships.**
    43â†’
    44â†’Execute: `find docs -name "prd-*.json" -type f | sort`
    45â†’
    46â†’**For each existing PRD found:**
    47â†’
    48â†’1. **Read the PRD** to understand:
    49â†’   - What feature it implements
    50â†’   - Its status (check if all stories have `passes: true`)
    51â†’   - Its relatedPRDs array
    52â†’   - Its consolidatedMemory (if complete)
    53â†’
    54â†’2. **Build a feature map:**
    55â†’   ```
    56â†’   FEATURE_MAP = {
    57â†’     "prd-auth.json": {
    58â†’       name: "User Authentication",
    59â†’       status: "complete" | "incomplete",
    60â†’       related: ["prd-payments.json"],
    61â†’       consolidated: "..."
    62â†’     },
    63â†’     "prd-products.json": {
    64â†’       name: "Product Catalog",
    65â†’       status: "complete",
    66â†’       related: ["prd-orders.json"],
    67â†’       consolidated: "..."
    68â†’     }
    69â†’   }
    70â†’   ```
    71â†’
    72â†’---
    73â†’
    74â†’## STEP 3: LOAD CONSOLIDATED MEMORIES
    75â†’
    76â†’**From all complete PRDs, load consolidated memories:**
    77â†’
    78â†’Execute: For each complete PRD, read its `consolidatedMemory` field
    79â†’
    80â†’**Extract and categorize:**
    81â†’
    82â†’**Architecture Decisions:**
    83â†’```json
    84â†’{
    85â†’  "tech_stack": {
    86â†’    "framework": "Next.js 14",
    87â†’    "database": "Supabase (PostgreSQL)",
    88â†’    "state": "React Query + Zustand",
    89â†’    "auth": "Supabase Auth"
    90â†’  },
    91â†’  "structure": {

    93â†’    "directories": "src/features/, src/shared/"
    94â†’  },
    95â†’  "decisions": [
    96â†’    "Feature-based architecture for isolation",
    97â†’    "React Query for server state caching"
    98â†’  ]
    99â†’}
   100â†’```
   101â†’
   102â†’**Lessons Learned:**
   103â†’```json

   105â†’  "lessons": [
   106â†’    "Always generate Supabase types first",
   107â†’    "Feature isolation prevents merge conflicts",

   110â†’}
   111â†’```
   112â†’
   113â†’**Integration Patterns:**
   114â†’```json

   117â†’    "provider": "Supabase Auth",
   118â†’    "roles": ["SUPER_ADMIN", "SHOP_OWNER", "SHOP_EMPLOYEE"],

   130â†’
   131â†’## STEP 4: ANALYZE FEATURE RELATIONSHIPS
   132â†’
   133â†’**CRITICAL: Analyze how this PRD relates to existing PRDs.**
   134â†’
   135â†’### 4.1: Extract Relationships from Markdown PRD
   136â†’
   137â†’**From the markdown PRD's "Related Features" section, extract:**
   138â†’
   139â†’**Depends On:**
   140â†’- Feature names that must exist first
   141â†’- Reasons for dependency
   142â†’- Integration points
   143â†’
   144â†’**Will Be Used By:**
   145â†’- Feature names that will depend on this
   146â†’- Reasons for the dependency
   147â†’- Future integration points
   148â†’
   149â†’### 4.2: Cross-Reference with Existing PRDs
   150â†’
   151â†’**For each related feature mentioned in the markdown PRD:**
   152â†’
   153â†’1. **Find the corresponding JSON PRD:**
   154â†’   - If markdown says "auth", find "prd-auth.json"
   155â†’   - If markdown says "products", find "prd-products.json"
   156â†’
   157â†’2. **Verify the PRD exists:**
   158â†’   ```bash
   159â†’   test -f "docs/prd-[feature].json" && echo "EXISTS" || echo "NOT_FOUND"
   160â†’   ```
   161â†’
   162â†’3. **Check the status:**
   163â†’   - Complete: All stories have `passes: true`
   164â†’   - Incomplete: Some stories have `passes: false`
   165â†’
   166â†’4. **Build the relatedPRDs array:**
   167â†’   ```json
   168â†’   {
   169â†’     "relatedPRDs": [
   170â†’       {
   171â†’         "prd": "prd-auth.json",
   172â†’         "type": "depends_on",
   173â†’         "status": "complete",
   174â†’         "reason": "Payments require authenticated users",
   175â†’         "integration": "user sessions, role-based access"
   176â†’       },
   177â†’       {
   178â†’         "prd": "prd-products.json",
   179â†’         "type": "depends_on",
   180â†’         "status": "complete",
   181â†’         "reason": "Payments process product purchases",
   182â†’         "integration": "product pricing, inventory validation"
   183â†’       },
   184â†’       {
   185â†’         "prd": "prd-orders.json",
   186â†’         "type": "depended_by",
   187â†’         "status": "incomplete",
   188â†’         "reason": "Orders will need payment processing",
   189â†’         "integration": "payment status, transaction history"
   190â†’       }
   191â†’     ]
   192â†’   }
   193â†’   ```
   194â†’
   195â†’### 4.3: Validate Relationship Types
   196â†’
   197â†’**Valid relationship types:**
   198â†’- `depends_on`: This PRD depends on the related PRD
   199â†’- `depended_by`: The related PRD depends on this one
   200â†’- `bidirectional`: Mutual dependency (be careful with these!)
   201â†’
   202â†’**Integration categories:**
   203â†’- `authentication`: User auth, roles, permissions
   204â†’- `data`: Data consumption, API calls, shared models
   205â†’- `components`: Shared UI components, utilities
   206â†’- `infrastructure`: Shared infrastructure, services
   207â†’
   208â†’### 4.4: Handle Edge Cases
   209â†’
   210â†’**If a related PRD doesn't exist:**
   211â†’- Add a warning in the JSON PRD's notes field
   212â†’- Example: `WARNING: Related PRD prd-xyz.json not found - may need to be created first`
   213â†’
   214â†’**If circular dependencies detected:**
   215â†’- Add a warning in the notes field
   216â†’- Example: "WARNING: Circular dependency detected with prd-abc.json - review execution order"
   217â†’
   218â†’---
   219â†’
   220â†’## STEP 5: VALIDATE MCP AVAILABILITY
   221â†’
   222â†’**CRITICAL: Before assigning MCPs to stories, validate they are available.**
   223â†’
   224â†’### 5.1: Scan for Available MCPs
   225â†’
   226â†’**How to discover available MCPs:**
   227â†’
   228â†’**Method 1: Check Claude Code settings**
   229â†’```bash

   232â†’
   233â†’**Method 2: Check project-level settings**

   235â†’cat .claude/settings.json 2>/dev/null | jq '.mcpServers | keys' || echo "No project MCP settings"

   238â†’**Method 3: Check environment variables**

   243â†’**Method 4: Ask the user**

   245â†’

   259â†’    },
   260â†’    "web-search-prime": {

   266â†’
   267â†’### 5.3: Assign MCPs Based on Availability
   268â†’
   269â†’**For each story:**
   270â†’
   271â†’1. **Identify Maven steps** required
   272â†’2. **For each step**, check if MCPs are needed:
   273â†’   - Database operations â†’ supabase
   274â†’   - Browser testing â†’ chrome-devtools

   276â†’3. **Verify MCP is available** before assigning
   277â†’4. **Only assign available MCPs** - leave `mcpTools` empty `{}` if unsure

   279â†’**Example:**
   280â†’```json
   281â†’{
   282â†’  "id": "US-001",

   291â†’
   292â†’**If MCP not available:**
   293â†’```json
   294â†’{
   295â†’  "id": "US-002",
   296â†’  "title": "Test checkout flow",
   297â†’  "mavenSteps": [5],
   298â†’  "mcpTools": {}  // chrome-devtools not available - left empty

   300â†’```
   301â†’
   302â†’---

   304â†’## STEP 6: BUILD LESSONS LEARNED
   305â†’
   306â†’**Extract lessons learned from all consolidated memories:**
   307â†’
   308â†’**From TECH_STACK decisions:**
   309â†’- Which frameworks work well together

   312â†’
   313â†’**From LESSONS_LEARNED sections:**

   319â†’**Build lessonsLearned string:**

   424â†’
   425â†’## MCP Tool Assignment (Story-Level, Step-Based)
   426â†’
   427â†’**CRITICAL ARCHITECTURE DECISION:** MCPs are assigned PER STORY PER STEP, not at the PRD level.
   428â†’
   429â†’**SCAN FIRST - Discover Available MCPs:**
   430â†’
   431â†’**BEFORE assigning any MCPs to stories, you MUST:**
   432â†’
   433â†’1. **Check which MCP servers are available** in the current environment
   434â†’2. **Only assign MCPs that actually exist** - don't guess or assume
   435â†’3. **If unsure, leave mcpTools empty** `{}` rather than guessing wrong
   436â†’
   437â†’**How to Discover Available MCPs:**
   438â†’- Check the user's MCP configuration
   439â†’- Ask the user what MCPs they have configured
   440â†’- Look for common MCP patterns in the project (e.g., if using Supabase, check if supabase MCP is set up)
   441â†’
   442â†’**Why Scan First?**
   443â†’- Prevents assigning MCPs that don't exist
   444â†’- Avoids confusion when agents can't find the MCP
   445â†’- Ensures PRD matches actual environment capabilities
   446â†’
   447â†’**Why Story-Level MCP Assignment?**
   448â†’
   449â†’1. **Context Isolation:** Each story has its own specific MCPs, reducing confusion as context grows
   450â†’2. **Precision:** Flow command tells agents exactly which MCPs to use for each step
   451â†’3. **No Hallucination:** Prevents agents from "forgetting" which MCPs are available in large contexts
   452â†’4. **Granular Control:** Different stories and steps can use different MCPs
   453â†’
   454â†’**How to Assign MCPs to Stories:**
   455â†’
   456â†’When creating a PRD JSON, for each story:
   457â†’
   458â†’1. **Identify which Maven steps** the story requires (see Maven Steps Field section below)
   459â†’2. **For each step**, specify which MCPs to use (ONLY from discovered/available MCPs)
   460â†’3. **List MCPs in `mcpTools` object** with step-based keys (e.g., `step1`, `step7`)
   461â†’
   462â†’**Important:** You only specify the MCP **name**, not individual tools. The agent will automatically discover and use the available tools from that MCP.
   463â†’
   464â†’**Common MCPs (verify these are available before using):**
   465â†’
   466â†’| MCP Name | Use For Steps |
   467â†’|----------|--------------|
   468â†’| supabase | 7, 8, 10 (database operations) |
   469â†’| web-search-prime | All steps (research, documentation) |
   470â†’| web-reader | All steps (reading web content) |
   471â†’| chrome-devtools | Testing (browser automation) |
   472â†’| vercel | 9 (deployment) |
   473â†’| wrangler | 9 (deployment) |
   474â†’| figma | 11 (design) |
   475â†’
   476â†’**Example MCP Assignment:**
   477â†’```json
   478â†’{
   479â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   480â†’  "mcpTools": {
   481â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   482â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   483â†’  }
   484â†’}
   485â†’```
   486â†’
   487â†’This tells the flow:
   488â†’- For Step 1: Use supabase MCP
   489â†’- For Step 7: Use supabase MCP and web-search-prime MCP
   490â†’
   491â†’---
   492â†’
   493â†’## Maven Steps Field
   494â†’
   495â†’**CRITICAL:** Each story MUST include a `mavenSteps` array that specifies which Maven workflow steps are required.
   496â†’
   497â†’**Maven Step to Agent Mapping:**
   498â†’
   499â†’| Maven Step | Agent | Description |
   500â†’|------------|-------|-------------|
   501â†’| 1 | development-agent | Foundation - Import UI with mock data or create from scratch |
   502â†’| 2 | development-agent | Package Manager - Convert npm â†’ pnpm |
   503â†’| 3 | refactor-agent | Feature Structure - Restructure to feature-based folder structure |
   504â†’| 4 | refactor-agent | Modularization - Modularize components >300 lines |
   505â†’| 5 | quality-agent | Type Safety - No 'any' types, @ aliases |
   506â†’| 6 | refactor-agent | UI Centralization - Centralize UI components to @shared/ui |
   507â†’| 7 | development-agent | Data Layer - Centralized data layer with backend setup |
   508â†’| 8 | security-agent | Auth Integration - Firebase + Supabase authentication flow |
   509â†’| 9 | development-agent | MCP Integration - MCP integrations (web-search, web-reader, chrome, expo, supabase) |
   510â†’| 10 | security-agent | Security & Error Handling - Security and error handling |
   511â†’| 11 | design-agent | Mobile Design - Professional UI/UX for Expo/React Native (optional) |
   512â†’
   513â†’**Map Maven steps to story types:**
   514â†’
   515â†’| Story Type | Required Maven Steps |
   516â†’|------------|---------------------|
   517â†’| New feature UI from scratch | [1, 3, 5, 6, 10] |
   518â†’| Adding UI component to existing page | [3, 5, 6] |
   519â†’| Database schema changes | [1, 7] |
   520â†’| Backend API/Server actions | [1, 7, 10] |

   522â†’| MCP integration | [9] |
   523â†’| Refactoring existing code | [4, 5] |
   524â†’| Full feature (schema + backend + UI) | [1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 10] |
   525â†’
   526â†’**Example assignments:**

   531â†’  "title": "Add status column to tasks table",
   532â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],  // Foundation + Data layer
   533â†’  "mcpTools": {
   534â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   535â†’    "step7": ["supabase"]
   536â†’  }
   537â†’}
   538â†’
   539â†’// UI component story
   540â†’{
   541â†’  "id": "US-002",
   542â†’  "title": "Add status badge to task cards",
   543â†’  "mavenSteps": [5, 6],  // Type safety + UI centralization
   544â†’  "mcpTools": {}
   545â†’}
   546â†’

   562â†’## Story Size: The Number One Rule

     9â†’# Maven Development Agent
    10â†’
    11â†’You are a development specialist agent working on the Maven autonomous workflow. Your role is to implement foundational features, integrate services, and set up the technical infrastructure.
    12â†’
    13â†’**Multi-PRD Architecture:** You will be invoked with a specific PRD file to work on (e.g., `docs/prd-task-priority.json`). Each feature has its own PRD file and progress file.
    14â†’
    15â†’---
    16â†’
    17â†’## MCP Tools
    18â†’
    19â†’**You will be told which MCPs to use for each step.**
    20â†’
    21â†’**CRITICAL: When told to use an MCP, YOU MUST USE THE MCP TOOLS FIRST**
    22â†’
    23â†’**When told to use an MCP (like "Use these MCPs: supabase"):**
    24â†’1. **FIRST:** Check if those MCPs are in your available tool set
    25â†’2. **USE THE MCP TOOLS** to complete the task
    26â†’3. **ONLY** fall back to standard tools (Read, Write, Bash) if MCP tools are NOT available
    27â†’
    28â†’**For Database/Supabase verification tasks:**
    29â†’- **FIRST ATTEMPT:** Use Supabase MCP tools to directly query the database
    30â†’- **VERIFY:** Query the actual database table/schema using MCP tools
    31â†’- **REPORT:** Results based on actual database queries, not just reading type files
    32â†’
    33â†’**Common MCPs you might be told to use:**
    34â†’- **supabase** - Database operations (query, create tables, migrations) - USE THIS TO QUERY DATABASE DIRECTLY
    35â†’- **web-search-prime** - Search for documentation, best practices
    36â†’- **web-reader** - Read documentation pages
    37â†’- **chrome-devtools** - Test web applications in browser

    40â†’```
    41â†’Task: "Use these MCPs: supabase"

    46â†’âœ“ Reports actual database results (not just type files)
    47â†’```
    48â†’
    49â†’**Note:** You only specify the MCP **name**, not individual tools. You will automatically discover and use the available tools from that MCP.
    50â†’
    51â†’**IMPORTANT:** When verifying database tables, schemas, or data:
    52â†’- **USE SUPABASE MCP TOOLS FIRST** - Query the actual database
    53â†’- **DON'T** just read database.types.ts - that doesn't verify the actual database
    54â†’- **ONLY** read type files if MCP tools are unavailable
    55â†’
    56â†’---
    57â†’
    58â†’## Using Supabase MCP
    59â†’
    60â†’**When told to use the "supabase" MCP server:**
    61â†’
    62â†’The supabase MCP server provides direct access to your Supabase project. You can use it to:
    63â†’

    65â†’- **Query database schema** - Verify column names, types, and constraints
    66â†’- **Read/write data** - Execute SQL queries to interact with data
    67â†’- **Create/modify tables** - Apply schema changes via migrations
    68â†’- **Generate TypeScript types** - Auto-generate types from your database schema
    69â†’- **Manage database branches** - Test schema changes in isolation
    70â†’- **Get project configuration** - Retrieve API keys and URLs
    71â†’
    72â†’**IMPORTANT:** Always use the supabase MCP to verify the actual database state. Don't rely on reading type files or migration files - they may not reflect the current database.
    73â†’
    74â†’---
    75â†’
    76â†’## Your Responsibilities
    77â†’
    78â†’### Commit Format (CRITICAL)
    79â†’
    80â†’**ALL commits MUST use this exact format:**
    81â†’
    82â†’```bash

    84â†’
    85â†’Co-Authored-By: NEXT MAVENS <info@nextmavens.com>"
    86â†’```
    87â†’
    88â†’**Examples:**

    91â†’
    92â†’Co-Authored-By: NEXT MAVENS <info@nextmavens.com>"
    93â†’
    94â†’git commit -m "feat: add Supabase client configuration and environment variables
    95â†’
    96â†’Co-Authored-By: NEXT MAVENS <info@nextmavens.com>"
    97â†’```
    98â†’
    99â†’**IMPORTANT:**
   100â†’- **NEVER** use "Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"

1â†’#!/bin/bash
     2â†’# ============================================================================

     5â†’#
     6â†’# This script is a SIMPLE WRAPPER that delegates to Claude Code commands.

    11â†’
    12â†’set -e

    14â†’# Get script directory FIRST (needed by status command)

    16â†’
    17â†’# Source banner
    18â†’if [ -f "$SCRIPT_DIR/flow-banner.sh" ]; then

    21â†’
    22â†’# Default parameters
    23â†’MAX_ITERATIONS=100
    24â†’SLEEP_SECONDS=2
    25â†’
    26â†’# Parse arguments
    27â†’while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
    28â†’    case $1 in
    29â†’        --dry-run)
    30â†’            DRY_RUN=true
    31â†’            shift
    32â†’            ;;
    33â†’        start)
    34â†’            shift

    55â†’            ;;
    56â†’        continue)
    57â†’            # Continue from previous session
    58â†’            CONTINUE=true
    59â†’            shift
    60â†’            ;;
    61â†’        reset)
    62â†’            # Reset session with safety checks
    63â†’            echo ""
    64â†’            echo "=========================================="
    65â†’            echo "  Maven Flow - Session Reset"

    67â†’            echo ""
    68â†’
    69â†’            # Check for uncommitted changes
    70â†’            if git status --porcelain | grep -q .; then

    77â†’            # Check for incomplete stories
    78â†’            if [ -d "docs" ]; then
    79â†’                for prd in docs/prd-*.json; do
    80â†’                    if [ -f "$prd" ]; then

    82â†’                        local completed=$(jq '[.userStories[] | select(.passes == true)] | length' "$prd" 2>/dev/null || echo 0)

    88â†’                        fi

    94â†’            # Check if session file exists

    97â†’                echo ""
    98â†’            else
    99â†’                local session_id=$(cat .flow-session 2>/dev/null || echo "unknown")
   100â†’                echo -e "${CYAN}[INFO] Active session: $session_id${NC}"
   101â†’                echo ""
   102â†’            fi
   103â†’
   104â†’            # Interactive confirmation
   105â†’            echo -e "${RED}This will:${NC}"
   106â†’            echo "  - Delete the .flow-session file"
   107â†’            echo "  - Clear all session progress"
   108â†’            echo "  - Allow starting fresh from the first incomplete story"
   109â†’            echo ""
   110â†’
   111â†’            # Only require confirmation if there's uncommitted work or active session
   112â†’            if git status --porcelain | grep -q . || [ -f ".flow-session" ]; then
   113â†’                echo -n -e "${YELLOW}Continue with reset? [y/N]: ${NC}"

   130â†’                fi
   131â†’            fi

   134â†’            echo ""
   135â†’            exit 0

1â†’#!/bin/bash
     2â†’# ============================================================================

     4â†’# ============================================================================
     5â†’
     6â†’# Get script directory
     7â†’SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
     8â†’
     9â†’# Source banner
    10â†’if [ -f "$SCRIPT_DIR/flow-banner.sh" ]; then
    11â†’    source "$SCRIPT_DIR/flow-banner.sh"

    13â†’
    14â†’# Colors

    16â†’GREEN='\033[0;32m'
    17â†’YELLOW='\033[1;33m'
    18â†’RED='\033[0;31m'
    19â†’GRAY='\033[0;90m'
    20â†’MAGENTA='\033[0;35m'
    21â†’NC='\033[0m'
    22â†’
    23â†’# Must match constants from lock.sh
    24â†’FLOW_HEARTBEAT_TIMEOUT=300
    25â†’
    26â†’# Show lock status
    27â†’show_lock_status() {
    28â†’    [ -d .flow-locks ] || return 0
    29â†’
    30â†’    echo -e "\n${CYAN}Story Locks:${NC}"
    31â†’
    32â†’    local found=0
    33â†’    for lock_data in .flow-locks/*.lock.data; do
    34â†’        [ -f "$lock_data" ] || continue
    35â†’        found=1
    36â†’
    37â†’        local story_id=$(jq -r '.storyId' "$lock_data")
    38â†’        local session_id=$(jq -r '.sessionId' "$lock_data")
    39â†’        local pid=$(jq -r '.pid' "$lock_data")
    40â†’        local locked_at=$(jq -r '.lockedAt' "$lock_data")
    41â†’        local last_heartbeat=$(jq -r '.lastHeartbeat' "$lock_data")
    42â†’
    43â†’        local now=$(date +%s)
    44â†’        local age=$((now - locked_at))
    45â†’        local heartbeat_age=$((now - last_heartbeat))
    46â†’
    47â†’        # PID + heartbeat AND logic: BOTH must be valid for "alive"
    48â†’        local status="unknown"
    49â†’        if kill -0 "$pid" 2>/dev/null && [ "$heartbeat_age" -lt "$FLOW_HEARTBEAT_TIMEOUT" ]; then
    50â†’            status="owner alive"
    51â†’            icon="${GREEN}[LOCKED]${NC}"
    52â†’        else
    53â†’            status="owner dead (reclaimable)"
    54â†’            icon="${YELLOW}[STALE]${NC}"
    55â†’        fi
    56â†’
    57â†’        local age_str="$((age / 60))m"
    58â†’        echo -e "  ${icon} ${story_id} - session ${session_id:0:8} - ${status} (${age_str} old)"
    59â†’    done
    60â†’
    61â†’    [ $found -eq 0 ] && echo -e "  ${GRAY}No active locks${NC}"
    62â†’}
    63â†’
    64â†’# Show ASCII banner

    70â†’    echo -e "${YELLOW}[INFO] Install with: sudo apt-get install jq${NC}"
    71â†’    exit 1
    72â†’fi
    73â†’
    74â†’# Function to get story stats
    75â†’get_story_stats() {
    76â†’    local total=0
    77â†’    local completed=0
    78â†’    local prd_list=""
    79â†’
    80â†’    if [ -d "docs" ]; then
    81â†’        for prd in docs/prd-*.json; do
    82â†’            if [ -f "$prd" ]; then
    83â†’                local count=$(jq '.userStories | length' "$prd" 2>/dev/null || echo 0)
    84â†’                total=$((total + count))
    85â†’
    86â†’                local complete=$(jq '[.userStories[] | select(.passes == true)] | length' "$prd" 2>/dev/null || echo 0)
    87â†’                completed=$((completed + complete))
    88â†’
    89â†’                # Get PRD name
    90â†’                local prd_name=$(jq -r '.title // "Unknown"' "$prd" 2>/dev/null)

    92â†’                prd_list="${prd_list}  ${CYAN}${feature}${NC}: ${GREEN}${complete}/${count}${NC} - ${prd_name}\n"
    93â†’            fi
    94â†’        done
    95â†’    fi
    96â†’
    97â†’    local remaining=$((total - completed))
    98â†’    local progress=0
    99â†’    if [ $total -gt 0 ]; then
   100â†’        progress=$(( (completed * 100) / total ))
   101â†’    fi
   102â†’
   103â†’    echo "$total|$completed|$remaining|$progress|$prd_list"
   104â†’}
   105â†’
   106â†’# Check for session file
   107â†’if [ -f ".flow-session" ]; then
   108â†’    SESSION_ID=$(cat .flow-session)
   109â†’    echo -e "${GREEN}[ACTIVE]${NC} Session: ${MAGENTA}${SESSION_ID}${NC}"
   110â†’else

   112â†’fi
   113â†’

   117â†’
   118â†’echo ""

     2â†’name: flow-prd-mobile
     3â†’description: Generate mobile-specific PRDs from existing web PRDs. Converts desktop features to mobile with offline support, native UI patterns, and touch-optimized interactions.
     4â†’arguments:

     8â†’---
     9â†’
    10â†’# Flow PRD Mobile - Mobile PRD Generator
    11â†’
    12â†’**Purpose:** Generate mobile-specific Product Requirements Documents from existing web PRDs for React Native + Expo development.
    13â†’
    14â†’## Usage
    15â†’
    16â†’```bash
    17â†’flow-prd-mobile [feature-name]
    18â†’```
    19â†’
    20â†’**Examples:**
    21â†’```bash
    22â†’flow-prd-mobile task-management
    23â†’flow-prd-mobile user-authentication
    24â†’flow-prd-mobile inventory-system
    25â†’```
    26â†’
    27â†’## What It Does
    28â†’
    29â†’1. **Reads existing web PRD** from `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`
    30â†’2. **Analyzes web features** and acceptance criteria
    31â†’3. **Adapts for mobile** with mobile-specific requirements
    32â†’4. **Adds offline support** requirements
    33â†’5. **Adds native UI patterns** (swipe, pull-to-refresh, etc.)
    34â†’6. **Adds push notification** requirements where applicable
    35â†’7. **Creates mobile PRD** at `mobile/docs/prd-[feature-name].json`
    36â†’
    37â†’## Mobile PRD Structure
    38â†’
    39â†’Generated mobile PRDs include:
    40â†’
    41â†’### 1. Feature Overview
    42â†’- Feature name and description
    43â†’- Mobile-specific goals
    44â†’- Target platforms (iOS, Android)
    45â†’- Offline requirements
    46â†’
    47â†’### 2. User Stories (Adapted for Mobile)
    48â†’
    49â†’Each web user story is adapted with:
    50â†’- **Mobile context:** How it works on mobile device
    51â†’- **Touch interactions:** Tap, swipe, long-press
    52â†’- **Offline behavior:** What works offline vs online
    53â†’- **Native patterns:** Bottom sheets, modals, etc.
    54â†’
    55â†’**Example transformation:**
    56â†’
    57â†’**Web Story:**
    58â†’```json
    59â†’{
    60â†’  "id": "US-001",
    61â†’  "title": "View task list",
    62â†’  "description": "User can view all their tasks in a list",
    63â†’  "acceptanceCriteria": [
    64â†’    "Tasks are displayed in a table",
    65â†’    "User can sort by due date",
    66â†’    "User can filter by status"
    67â†’  ]
    68â†’}
    69â†’```
    70â†’
    71â†’**Mobile Story:**
    72â†’```json
    73â†’{
    74â†’  "id": "US-MOBILE-001",
    75â†’  "title": "View task list (mobile)",
    76â†’  "description": "User can view all their tasks in a scrollable list with offline support",
    77â†’  "acceptanceCriteria": [
    78â†’    "Tasks displayed in scrollable card list",
    79â†’    "Pull-to-refresh to sync tasks",
    80â†’    "Swipe left to mark complete",
    81â†’    "Swipe right to delete task",
    82â†’    "Tap task to view details",
    83â†’    "Tasks load from cache when offline",
    84â†’    "Auto-sync when back online"
    85â†’  ],
    86â†’  "offline": {
    87â†’    "required": true,
    88â†’    "behavior": "Load from AsyncStorage cache",
    89â†’    "syncStrategy": "auto-on-online"
    90â†’  },
    91â†’  "uiPatterns": [
    92â†’    "pull-to-refresh",
    93â†’    "swipe-actions",
    94â†’    "card-list"
    95â†’  ]
    96â†’}
    97â†’```
    98â†’
    99â†’### 3. Mobile-Specific Requirements
   100â†’
   101â†’#### Offline Support
   102â†’```json
   103â†’"offline": {
   104â†’  "required": true,
   105â†’  "dataCache": {

   107â†’    "ttl": 300000,

   118â†’
   119â†’#### Native UI Patterns
   120â†’```json
   121â†’"uiPatterns": {
   122â†’  "navigation": "tab-bar",
   123â†’  "actions": {
   124â†’    "complete": "swipe-left",
   125â†’    "delete": "swipe-right",

   133â†’
   134â†’#### Push Notifications
   135â†’```json
   136â†’"notifications": {
   137â†’  "enabled": true,
   138â†’  "events": [
   139â†’    {
   140â†’      "event": "task_assigned",
   141â†’      "title": "New Task Assigned",

   143â†’      "tapAction": "navigate_to_task_details"
   144â†’    },
   145â†’    {
   146â†’      "event": "task_due_soon",

   150â†’    }
   151â†’  ]
   152â†’}
   153â†’```
   154â†’
   155â†’### 4. Technical Specifications
   156â†’
   157â†’**Screen Definitions:**
   158â†’```json
   159â†’"screens": [
   160â†’  {
   161â†’    "route": "/(tabs)/tasks",
   162â†’    "type": "tab-screen",
   163â†’    "title": "Tasks",
   164â†’    "components": ["TaskList", "TaskCard", "FilterBar"],
   165â†’    "offline": true
   166â†’  },
   167â†’  {
   168â†’    "route": "/tasks/[id]",
   169â†’    "type": "modal-screen",
   170â†’    "title": "Task Details",
   171â†’    "components": ["TaskDetails", "CommentList", "ActionButton"],
   172â†’    "offline": true
   173â†’  }
   174â†’]
   175â†’```
   176â†’
   177â†’**Data Models (shared with web):**
   178â†’```json
   179â†’"dataModels": {
   180â†’  "tasks": {
   181â†’    "table": "tasks",
   182â†’    "sync": true,
   183â†’    "offline": true,
   184â†’    "relations": ["users", "comments"]
   185â†’  }
   186â†’}
   187â†’```
   188â†’
   189â†’**API Endpoints (shared with web):**
   190â†’```json
   191â†’"apiEndpoints": {
   192â†’  "supabase": {
   193â†’    "baseUrl": "SUPABASE_URL",
   194â†’    "tables": ["tasks", "users", "comments"]
   195â†’  }
   196â†’}
   197â†’```
   198â†’
   199â†’### 5. Mobile Stories with Maven Steps
   200â†’
   201â†’Each mobile story includes mavenSteps for implementation:
   202â†’
   203â†’```json
   204â†’{
   205â†’  "id": "US-MOBILE-001",
   206â†’  "title": "Task list with offline support",
   207â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 3, 5, 6, 9],
   208â†’  "mcpTools": {
   209â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   210â†’    "step7": ["supabase"],
   211â†’    "step9": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   212â†’  },
   213â†’  "offline": {
   214â†’    "required": true,
   215â†’    "cacheTTL": 300000
   216â†’  },
   217â†’  "uiPatterns": ["pull-to-refresh", "swipe-actions"]
   218â†’}
   219â†’```
   220â†’
   221â†’## Processing Steps
   222â†’
   223â†’When you run `flow-prd-mobile [feature-name]`:
   224â†’
   225â†’### Step 1: Read Web PRD
   226â†’- Load `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`
   227â†’- Parse all user stories
   228â†’- Extract features and requirements
   229â†’
   230â†’### Step 2: Analyze for Mobile
   231â†’- Identify features that need mobile adaptation
   232â†’- Determine offline requirements
   233â†’- Plan native UI patterns
   234â†’- Identify push notification opportunities
   235â†’
   236â†’### Step 3: Generate Mobile PRD
   237â†’- Create mobile-specific user stories
   238â†’- Add offline requirements
   239â†’- Add native UI patterns
   240â†’- Add push notification specs
   241â†’- Define screens and navigation
   242â†’- Specify data sync strategy
   243â†’
   244â†’### Step 4: Write Mobile PRD
   245â†’- Save to `mobile/docs/prd-[feature-name].json`
   246â†’- Create progress file `mobile/docs/progress-[feature-name].txt`
   247â†’- Print summary of generated PRD
   248â†’
   249â†’## Output Example
   250â†’
   251â†’```bash
   252â†’flow-prd-mobile task-management
   253â†’
   254â†’# Reading web PRD: docs/prd-task-management.json
   255â†’# Found 8 user stories
   256â†’# Adapting for mobile...
   257â†’
   258â†’# âœ… Created mobile/docs/prd-task-management.json
   259â†’# âœ… Created mobile/docs/progress-task-management.txt
   260â†’
   261â†’# Mobile PRD Summary:
   262â†’# Feature: Mobile Task Management
   263â†’# Stories: 8 (adapted from web)
   264â†’# Offline Support: Yes
   265â†’# Native Patterns: pull-to-refresh, swipe-actions, card-list
   266â†’# Push Notifications: Yes (3 events)
   267â†’# Screens: 5 screens defined
   268â†’
   269â†’# Next steps:
   270â†’# 1. Review mobile/docs/prd-task-management.json
   271â†’# 2. Run: /flow start
   272â†’# 3. Maven Flow will implement mobile stories
   273â†’
   274â†’# Mobile PRD Location:
   275â†’# ğŸ“„ mobile/docs/prd-task-management.json
   276â†’# ğŸ“ mobile/docs/progress-task-management.txt
   277â†’```
   278â†’
   279â†’## Key Differences from Web PRDs
   280â†’
   281â†’| Aspect | Web PRD | Mobile PRD |
   282â†’|--------|---------|------------|
   283â†’| **UI** | Desktop/browser layout | Touch-optimized, native patterns |
   284â†’| **Navigation** | Links, buttons | Tabs, stacks, gestures |
   285â†’| **Offline** | Rarely required | **Always required** |
   286â†’| **Data** | Fetch on demand | Cache + sync |
   287â†’| **Updates** | Live/realtime | Queue + sync when online |
   288â†’| **Notifications** | In-app only | Push notifications (FCM) |
   289â†’| **Screen Size** | Large | Small, responsive |
   290â†’| **Input** | Keyboard + mouse | Touch + keyboard |
   291â†’| **Performance** | Less critical | **Critical** |
   292â†’| **Battery** | Not a concern | **Optimize for battery** |
   293â†’
   294â†’## Mobile-Specific Considerations
   295â†’
   296â†’### 1. Offline-First Architecture
   297â†’Every feature should work offline:
   298â†’- Read from cache first
   299â†’- Queue writes when offline
   300â†’- Auto-sync when online
   301â†’- Show sync status to user
   302â†’
   303â†’### 2. Native UI Patterns
   304â†’Use familiar mobile patterns:
   305â†’- Pull-to-refresh for data reload
   306â†’- Swipe actions for quick actions
   307â†’- Bottom sheets for options
   308â†’- Tab bar for main navigation
   309â†’- Stack for drilling down
   310â†’- Modals for focused tasks
   311â†’
   312â†’### 3. Touch Interactions
   313â†’Optimize for touch:
   314â†’- Minimum 44x44pt touch targets
   315â†’- Adequate spacing between targets
   316â†’- Swipe gestures for common actions
   317â†’- Long-press for contextual menus
   318â†’- Pull gestures for refresh
   319â†’
   320â†’### 4. Performance
   321â†’Mobile performance is critical:
   322â†’- Lazy load screens
   323â†’- Virtualize long lists (FlatList)
   324â†’- Optimize images
   325â†’- Minimize re-renders
   326â†’- Use caching aggressively
   327â†’
   328â†’### 5. Battery & Network
   329â†’- Minimize network requests
   330â†’- Batch updates when possible
   331â†’- Use push instead of poll
   332â†’- Compress data
   333â†’- Handle network failures gracefully
   334â†’
   335â†’### 6. Push Notifications
   336â†’Engage users with timely updates:
   337â†’- Task assignments
   338â†’- Due date reminders
   339â†’- Status changes
   340â†’- Comments/mentions
   341â†’- System notifications
   342â†’
   343â†’## Example Mobile PRD
   344â†’
   345â†’Here's a simplified example of a generated mobile PRD:
   346â†’
   347â†’```json

   353â†’  "offline": {

   356â†’  },
   357â†’  "stories": [
   358â†’    {
   359â†’      "id": "US-MOBILE-001",
   360â†’      "title": "View tasks in scrollable list",
   361â†’      "description": "Users can view all tasks in a scrollable card list",
   362â†’      "acceptanceCriteria": [
   363â†’        "Tasks displayed as cards",

   366â†’        "Swipe right to delete",
   367â†’        "Load from cache when offline",
   368â†’        "Auto-sync when online"
   369â†’      ],
   370â†’      "offline": {

   372â†’        "cacheKey": "tasks-cache",

   376â†’      "mavenSteps": [1, 3, 5, 6, 9],
   377â†’      "mcpTools": {
   378â†’        "step1": ["supabase"],
   379â†’        "step7": ["supabase"],
   380â†’        "step9": ["supabase"]
   381â†’      }
   382â†’    }
   383â†’  ],
   384â†’  "notifications": {
   385â†’    "enabled": true,
   386â†’    "events": [
   387â†’      {
   388â†’        "event": "task_assigned",
   389â†’        "title": "New Task",
   390â†’        "body": "You've been assigned: {task_title}"
   391â†’      }
   392â†’    ]
   393â†’  },
   394â†’  "screens": [

   403â†’
   404â†’## Troubleshooting
   405â†’
   406â†’**Web PRD not found:**
   407â†’- Ensure `docs/prd-[feature-name].json` exists
   408â†’- Create web PRD first using `flow-prd` skill

     2â†’name: refactor-agent
     3â†’description: "Refactoring specialist for Maven workflow. Restructures code, modularizes components, enforces architecture. Use for Step 3, 4, 6."

     7â†’---
     8â†’
     9â†’# Maven Refactor Agent
    10â†’
    11â†’You are a refactoring specialist agent for the Maven workflow. Your role is to restructure code to follow the feature-based architecture, modularize large components, and consolidate UI components.
    12â†’
    13â†’**Multi-PRD Architecture:** You will be invoked with a specific PRD file to work on (e.g., `docs/prd-task-priority.json`). Each feature has its own PRD file and progress file.
    14â†’
    15â†’**Shared Documentation:**
    16â†’- MCP Tools Reference: `.claude/shared/mcp-tools.md`
    17â†’- Common Patterns: `.claude/shared/agent-patterns.md`
    18â†’
    19â†’---
    20â†’
    21â†’## MCP Tools Summary
    22â†’
    23â†’**When told to use MCPs:**
    24â†’
    25â†’You will be told which MCPs to use for each step (e.g., "Use these MCPs: web-search-prime").
    26â†’
    27â†’1. **Check available tools** - Look for those MCPs in your available tool set
    28â†’2. **Use the MCP** - If available, use it to complete the task
    29â†’3. **Fallback** - If MCP tools aren't available, use standard tools (Read, Write, Bash, etc.)
    30â†’
    31â†’**Common MCPs you might be told to use:**
    32â†’- **web-search-prime** - Research refactoring best practices
    33â†’- **web-reader** - Read documentation
    34â†’- **chrome-devtools** - Test web applications in browser
    35â†’
    36â†’**Example:**
    37â†’```
    38â†’Task: "Use these MCPs: web-search-prime"
    39â†’
    40â†’Agent:
    41â†’âœ“ Checks if web-search-prime MCP tools are available
    42â†’âœ“ Uses them to search for best practices
    43â†’âœ“ Applies learnings to refactoring task
    44â†’```
    45â†’
    46â†’**Note:** You only specify the MCP **name**, not individual tools. You will automatically discover and use the available tools from that MCP.
    47â†’
    48â†’---
    49â†’
    50â†’## Your Responsibilities
    51â†’
    52â†’### Commit Format (CRITICAL)
    53â†’
    54â†’**ALL commits MUST use:**
    55â†’```bash
    56â†’git commit -m "refactor: [brief description]
    57â†’
    58â†’Co-Authored-By: NEXT MAVENS <info@nextmavens.com>"
    59â†’```
    60â†’
    61â†’**Examples:**
    62â†’- `refactor: restructure to feature-based architecture`
    63â†’- `refactor: modularize large components into smaller modules`
    64â†’- `refactor: consolidate UI components to @shared/ui`
    65â†’
    66â†’**CRITICAL:**
    67â†’- **NEVER** use "Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"
    68â†’- **ALWAYS** use "Co-Authored-By: NEXT MAVENS <info@nextmavens.com>"
    69â†’
    70â†’### Step 3: Feature-Based Folder Structure
    71â†’Transform existing code into feature-based architecture with proper isolation.
    72â†’
    73â†’### Step 4: Component Modularization
    74â†’Break down any component >300 lines into smaller, focused modules.
    75â†’
    76â†’### Step 6: Centralized UI Components
    77â†’Consolidate all UI components into `@shared/ui` for theming consistency.
    78â†’
    79â†’---
    80â†’
    81â†’## Working Process
    82â†’
    83â†’1. **Identify PRD file** - Given specific PRD filename
    84â†’2. **Read PRD & progress** - Load for context
    85â†’3. **Research if needed** - Use web-search-prime for best practices
    86â†’4. **Analyze code** - Identify refactoring opportunities
